title: Energy conservation spring launcher on asteroid

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. An astronaut is on a small asteroid that is a sphere of uniform density, as shown in the figure. The asteroid has a mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> and radius <math alttext="R sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, which are small compared to the mass and the radius of Earth. The astronaut has a vertical spring launcher, which uses a spring of spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> to launch two small spheres, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Spheres <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> have the same diameter but different masses <math alttext="lowercase m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="lowercase m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively, where <math alttext="lowercase m sub 2 is greater than lowercase m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The launcher is capable of launching the spheres to heights where the gravitational acceleration is significantly less than the gravitational acceleration near the asteroid’s surface. The astronaut first launches Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> by placing it on the launcher, compressing the launcher’s spring a distance <math alttext="delta x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and releasing the spring. After being launched, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> reaches a maximum height that is a distance <math alttext="D sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the center of the asteroid. Next, the astronaut launches Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> several times and determines the spring compression distance <math alttext="delta x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> that results in Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> reaching the same maximum distance <math alttext="D sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the asteroid’s center that was reached by Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. (a) Indicate how <math alttext="delta x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="delta x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> compare to each other._____<math alttext="delta x sub 1 is greater than delta x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>Without referring to or manipulating equations, justify your answer.

The launcher is capable of launching the spheres to heights where the gravitational acceleration is significantly less than the gravitational acceleration near the asteroid’s surface. The astronaut first launches Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> by placing it on the launcher, compressing the launcher’s spring a distance <math alttext="delta x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and releasing the spring. After being launched, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> reaches a maximum height that is a distance <math alttext="D sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the center of the asteroid. (b) Derive an equation for <math alttext="D sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="uppercase M sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="R sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Assume that the spring length and <math alttext="delta x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> are both small compared to <math alttext="R sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>.
(c) Indicate whether the equation you derived in part (b) is consistent with the claim you selected in part (a). Justify why the two answers are or are not consistent.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
